about.title: What is this?
about.body: This is a text message alert system to inform residents around KCBX Terminals that windspeed is high, and that they are therefore at increased risk of exposure to petroleum coke ("petcoke"). If you enter your phone number above, we will alert you when winds exceed 15 mph, the level deemed hazardous by the Chicago Department of Public Health. Longterm studies by Harvard University and the American Cancer Society have concluded that prolonged exposure to particulate matter such as petcoke increases the risk of heart disease and may increase the risk of lung cancer.

act.title: What can I do?
act.body-strong: Call the Mayor's office and demand ZERO THROUGHPUT for ALL TERMINALS at KCBX.
act.body-main: Each text message will contain a link to a webpage containing a phone number for the Mayor's office, as well as a script that you can read from to demand that KCBX stops polluting our homes and neighborhoods. We urge you to call EVERY TIME you receive a text, in order to create a public outcry that the Mayor can't ignore.

off-list.title: How can I unsubscribe?
off-list.body:
To unsubscribe, text "UNSUBSCRIBE" to 312-313-3200.
You will receive a response text confirming that you have canceled your subscription.

points.definition: Petcoke is short for Petroleum Coke.  It is a waste byproduct of the oil refining process that can be sold for use in some manufacturing processes.
points.risk: Petcoke dust is extremely fine, and when it becomes airborne can cause long- and short-term damage to the heart and lungs.
points.kcbx: KCBX Terminals, Inc. maintains two massive, open-air stockpiles of petcoke on Chicago's Southeast side in the immediate vicinity of a residential neighborhood, exposing thousands of Chicagoans to windblown particulate matter.

what-can-i-do.title: What can I do?
what-can-i-do.activism: Join activist groups like the Southeast Side Coalition to Ban Petcoke or the Southeast Environmental Task Force
what-can-i-do.share: Share information about and pictures of Petcoke on Twitter or Facebook to educate people about Petcoke and the lack of Social Justice on Chicago's Southeast Side
what-can-i-do.alderwoman: Join the Tenth Ward Alderwoman, Susan Sadlowski Garza, in speaking out against petcoke and air quality issues in your neighborhood.
